column4: can someone tell me if users currently have read only perms on other users home dirs?

well the reason im asking is im giving users access through usermin and at the moment they have read permissions on other users home dirs, if i was to chmod /home recursively to 700 would that give everyone except the owner and root permissions of 0?
so whats the default numerical permissions incase i mess up?
another thing is, i have all my samba stuff in /home like my public folder and stuff, what would be the effect of that command on those?
is there a way of having that command ignore the folder called "samba" ?
no affect at all. Samba permissions are set in /etc/samba/smb.conf
so for example if i was to run that command on /home then it wont mean stuff happens like users cant write to public and stuff?
the directives in smb.conf (allowed users, admin users) are what sets those permissions in samba
what is the best way of giving users permissions of 0 on anything that they dont own, would it be "chmod -R 700 /home"?
ah right ok, and if it messes up i can get it back using a chmod of 755 recursive?
letter format for chmod is   chmod [options] [(u)ser (g)roup (o)ther] [(r)ead (w)rite e(x)ecute (s)pecial/sticky ]
heh, i prefer numbers :P to letters - the letters confuse me :)
